answers.answer: Hello and thank you for visiting MedHelp.  It sounds like you are very aware of the risks of type 2 diabetes and are trying to avoid any complications by careful monitoring.  This is always a good idea.  Better to overload your doctor with too much information rather than not enough.I will answer your questions as best as possible, but a couple warnings first.  I am not a doctor, you should always talk to your doctor about your health.  We have our averages we work with, but your doctor knows what is best for you.  Secondly, I am more familiar with type 1 diabetes.  The ranges are pretty similar, but not exactly.  Now on to the answers.I found a website that might help you out a little.  Its address ishttp://diabetes.niddk.nih.gov/dm/pubs/type1and2/print_chart_1.htm#1That is a chart with the approximate target levels for blood sugar.  It has targets for before and after eating.  Basically between meals you want your blood sugar in the 90-130 range between meals, and below 180 after.  The most common number thrown around is below 100 between meals.  I have heard arguments for and against that low of a number though.Please stay in touch with your doctor.  If you stay on top of things you she be looking forward to a long, healthy, diabetes free life.
